Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Archaeological: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for textiles recovered as part of formal and unpermitted archaeological excavations. Most of the textiles in this file are from sites associated with the Diné (Navajo).

Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: California Academy of Sciences: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for textiles in the collections of the California Academy of Sciences. Joe Ben Wheat analyzed these textiles most likely as part of a project to compile a catalog for CAS of material from their "Elkus" collection, a substantial collection of Southwest Native art. The catalog, "The Elkus Collection: Southwestern Indian Art" was published in 1984.
Subject Geographic#1: Navajo Nation, Arizona, New Mexico & Utah

Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Commercial cloth / Bayeta: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for textiles woven of raveled commercial cloth, also known as bayeta. Bayeta is a form of cloth imported to Spanish America which was raveled, i.e. taken apart, to be rewoven. It was frequently used in this way by Diné (Navajo) weavers.

Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Diyugis: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for diyugis. A diyugi (diyogí) is a kind of Diné (Navajo) blanket characterized by large-diameter, handspun yarns. The name 'diyugi' comes from the Diné word diyogí meaning 'soft' or 'fluffy.' The diyugi was an everday blanket with a variety of purposes included wearing for warmth, as a pad for sleeping on, or for hanging over the doors of a hogan.
Subject Geographic#1: Navajo Nation, Arizona, New Mexico & Utah
Access Condition#1: This Item is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use this Item in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Germantown 4-ply: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for rugs and blankets woven from 4-ply Germantown yarn. Germantown yarn is named after its place of manufacture in Pennsylvania. Four-ply yarns from Germantown were used by Navajo weavers around 1875. These yarns had afine texture and wide range of colors that made them suitable for weaving textiles with fine detail. Germantown yarn is associated with eye dazzler blankets, saddle throws, fancy rugs, table runners, and pillow tops. The practice of weaving with Germantown yarn ceased in approximatley 1900.
Subject Geographic#1: Navajo Nation, Arizona, New Mexico & Utah
Access Condition#1: This Item is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use this Item in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Mantas, blue borders, fancy, white center, two-piece dresses: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for a variety textile forms, all of which are types of manta or other wearing garment. A manta is a one-piece garment worn as a shawl or sewn into a one-piece dress. Blue-borders is a Diné (Navajo) subtype of manta which is similar to a Pueblo manta dress but characterized by tapestry twill. Diné fancy mantas were a continuation of earlier one-piece dresses or mantas and were worn as shawls or blankets. Gradually the fancy manta (shawl) transitioned from a open twill weave to a tapestry weave and included designs typical of other tapestry weaves. The term "white center" in the title of this file refers to a design element used in certain mantas. Finally, a two-piece dress is a Diné garment consisting of two identical blankets sewn together at the shoulder and along the sides to create a single garment.
Subject Geographic#1: Navajo Nation, Arizona, New Mexico & Utah
Access Condition#1: This Item is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use this Item in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Pueblos and Hopi textiles: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for Pueblo and Hopi textiles. Pueblos specifically mentioned in this file include Acoma, Jemez, San Ildefonso, Santo Domingo, Tesuque, and Zuni. Many of the attributions to specific Pueblos are surrounded in quotes perhaps indicating that the attribution is uncertain. Other attributions mention more than one Pueblo, for instance "Acoma or Zuni." These attributions were made by anthropologist Joe Ben Wheat and reflect his particular understanding of textile production. In some cases, Wheat notes that a textile was attributed to one Pueblo by a museum but then corrects that attribtuion by supplying a different attribution of his own.
Subject Geographic#1: Navajo Nation, Arizona, New Mexico & Utah

Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Sarapes, classic: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for the Classic Period of sarape weaving. A sarape is a large, rectangular garment worn as outerwear. The Classic Period of sarapes is distinguished by its common color scheme: a ground of crimson with designs in indigo blue and white. Wheat defined this period of sarapes as spanning from 1800 to the early 1860s.
Subject Geographic#1: Navajo Nation, Arizona, New Mexico & Utah
Access Condition#1: This Item is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use this Item in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Serapes, late classic and handspun: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for Diné (Navajo) serapes from the late classic period made entirely or partially of handspun yarn. As defined by Joe Ben Wheat, the late classic period of Diné serapes began with the forced removal of Diné people to Bosque Redondo in 1863 and continued until the early 1870s.
Subject Geographic#1: Navajo Nation, Arizona, New Mexico & Utah

Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Serapes, Moki patterns and Navajo: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for Diné (Navajo) blankets with the Moki design. According to Joe Ben Wheat, the Moki design was introduced to the Southwest by the Spanish around 1630 and consisted of alternating blue, black, or brown stripes with white stripes. "Moki" is a name formerly used for the Hopi Tribe. Wheat notes that relatively few Moki design blankets were produced by Hopi weavers. In that sense, the term may be a misnomer.
Subject Geographic#1: Navajo Nation, Arizona, New Mexico & Utah

Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Shoulder blankets (male and female): textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for Diné (Navajo) men and women's shoulder blankets. Wheat indicates that there is a close relationship -- and possibly no true distinction -- between chief's blankets and shoulder blankets, remarking of women's shoulder blankets that "With some variation, all of the patterns made for men's chief blakets were also woven for women. These shoulder blankets were generally smaller than tose for men and usually had narrower stripes of gray or white rather than broad black and white stripes." Wheat does not comment specifically on the difference between men's shoulder blankets and women's should blankets nor men's shoulder blankets and chief's blankets.
Subject Geographic#1: Navajo Nation, Arizona, New Mexico & Utah
Access Condition#1: This Item is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use this Item in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Slave blankets: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for a genre of textile known as the slave blankets. Slave blanket is a term for blankets produced by Diné (Navajo) people who were slaves in Spanish and American households. Diné people were forced into slavery as until the 1870s, part of a larger pattern of the enslavement of indigenous peoples in America following European colonization. The blankets woven by these individuals have unique characteristics, namely a blend of Diné and Spanish Colonial (Old Rio Grande) characteristics.
Subject Geographic#1: Navajo Nation, Arizona, New Mexico & Utah

Title#1: Various private collections: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for textile in the private collections of Harris Thompson, Gary Carlson, Paul Harbaugh, and fourth but illegible collector. Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Wedgeweaves and two face: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for Diné (Navajo) textiles produced using a technique known as wedge weave. Wedge weave is a variation of the weft-faced plain weave technique. It is common in Europe but rare in the Southwest. Textiles woven using this technique consist of many colors, typically six to ten. Textiles of this type appeared, according to Joe Ben Wheat, in the 1870s and are not common after the 1890s. The file also contains analysis sheets for textiles woven using the two face technique. Two-faced or double-faced weaves have different patterns on each side of the textile.
Subject Geographic#1: Navajo Nation, Arizona, New Mexico & Utah

Collection Name: CU Museum of Natural History: Joe Ben Wheat Collection on Textiles
Title#1: Women's two-piece dresses: textile analysis sheets
Abstract#1: This file contains textile analysis sheets for Diné (Navajo) two-piece dresses. A two-piece dress is a Navajo garment consisting of two identical blankets sewn together at the shoulder and along the sides to create a single garment.
Subject Geographic#1: Navajo Nation, Arizona, New Mexico & Utah
